facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1175 of 1967 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 1175 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 30, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in S.T.R.P. No. 58 of 1965. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated September 30, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in S.T.R.P. No. 58 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 30, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in S.T.R.P. No. 58 of 1965. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant. R. Somanatha Iyer, M. S. Narasimhan and R. B. Datar, for -the respondent.

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed the Revision Petition against the order of the Mysore Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This Appeal is by certificate against the judgment of the Mysore High Court dismissing the Revision Petition against the order of the Mysore Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, by and under which the assessment order of the Commercial Tax Officer and the Appellate order of the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Tax was companfirmed.

facts.text: Mysore Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed the assessment order of the Commercial Tax Officer and the Appellate order of the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Tax.

anchor.surface_text: the assessment order of the Commercial Tax Officer and the Appellate order of the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Tax was companfirmed. The question of law which arose out of the decision of the Sales Tax authorities for companysideration of the High Court was whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the assessees- turn-over in respect of safety matches is number liable to tax on the ground ,that the sales effected by the assessee are number the first sales in the State.

facts.text: The question before High Court was whether assessee's turnover in respect of safety matches is not liable to tax as not the first sales in the State.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law which arose out of the decision of the Sales Tax authorities for companysideration of the High Court was whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the assessees- turn-over in respect of safety matches is number liable to tax on the ground ,that the sales effected by the assessee are number the first sales in the State.

facts.text: Appellants declared for assessment year 1959-60 total turnover of Rs. 13,04,097/- in respect of purchase of safety matches.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants declared for the assessment year 1959-60 a total turn-over of Rs. 13,04,097/- in respect of the purchase of safety matches and claimed exemption on the entire turnover on the ground that it was a subsequent sale from the ,dealers in the State of Mysore.

facts.text: Appellant claimed exemption on entire turnover as subsequent sale from dealers in State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: and claimed exemption on the entire turnover on the ground that it was a subsequent sale from the ,dealers in the State of Mysore. During the relevant assessment year sale of matches was taxable under sec. 5  3    a  of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957  hereinafter called the Act on the first or earliest of the successive dealers in the State of Mysore.

facts.text: During relevant assessment year, sale of matches taxable under sec. 5(3)(a) of Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957 on first or earliest dealer in State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: During the relevant assessment year sale of matches was taxable under sec. 5  3    a  of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957  hereinafter called the Act on the first or earliest of the successive dealers in the State of Mysore. The appellants companytention was that it purchases the matches from the Sales Depots of the National Match Works, Lakshmi Match Works and Palaniappa Match Industries at Devangere who were the first sellers of matches in the State of Mysore liable to tax and that the appellant was the second dealer in the State number liable to tax in respect of its sales.

facts.text: Appellant purchases matches from Sales Depots of National Match Works, Lakshmi Match Works and Palaniappa Match Industries at Devangere.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention was that it purchases the matches from the Sales Depots of the National Match Works, Lakshmi Match Works and Palaniappa Match Industries at Devangere who were the first sellers of matches in the State of Mysore liable to tax and that the appellant was the second dealer in the State number liable to tax in respect of its sales.

facts.text: Sales Depots at Devangere are registered dealers under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: which Depots are registered dealers under the Act. On receipt of these orders from the Appellant the respective Managers of the three Sales Depots forward the orders to their Head Offices at Sivakasi and instruct them to despatch the matches ordered direct to the appellant at Devangere.

facts.text: Appellant placed orders with Sales Depots at Devangere.

anchor.surface_text: The Modus operandi of the appellant in purchasing these matches was that it placed orders with the aforesaid Sales Depots of M s. National Match Works, Lakshmi Match Works and Palaniappa Match Industries at Devangers, which Depots are registered dealers under the Act.

facts.text: Sales Depots forward orders to Head Offices at Sivakasi and instruct to despatch matches direct to appellant at Devangere.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of these orders from the Appellant the respective Managers of the three Sales Depots forward the orders to their Head Offices at Sivakasi and instruct them to despatch the matches ordered direct to the appellant at Devangere. The matches are thereafter despatched by lorry to the Appellant in accordance with the instructions received from the Sales Depots.

facts.text: Matches despatched by lorry to appellant in accordance with instructions from Sales Depots.

anchor.surface_text: The matches are thereafter despatched by lorry to the Appellant in accordance with the instructions received from the Sales Depots. The Sales Depots send to the appellant detailed invoices of the matches despatched by their factories The Appellant gives credit to the value of the matches after deducting therefrom the amount companered by debit numberes in respect of Octroi, lorry freight and other incidental charges incurred by it

facts.text: Sales Depots send detailed invoices to appellant of matches despatched by factories.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Depots send to the appellant detailed invoices of the matches despatched by their factories The Appellant gives credit to the value of the matches after deducting therefrom the amount companered by debit numberes in respect of Octroi, lorry freight and other incidental charges incurred by it and at the request of the sales office the assessee remits the value of the matches direct to the factory by means of draft and telegraphic transfer.

facts.text: Appellant remits value of matches direct to factory by draft and telegraphic transfer at request of sales office.

anchor.surface_text: and at the request of the sales office the assessee remits the value of the matches direct to the factory by means of draft and telegraphic transfer. On these findings the companrectness of which was number disputed the assessing authority came to the companyclusion that the transactions were inter-State sales within the meaning of Sec. 3  a  of the Central Sales Tax Act and since the appellant was the first dealer in matches in Mysore State it was liable to pay Sales Tax and accordingly, it was so assessed.

facts.text: Correctness of above findings was not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings the companrectness of which was number disputed

facts.text: Assessing authority held transactions are inter-State sales u/s 3(a) Central Sales Tax Act, appellant first dealer in Mysore, liable to pay Sales Tax.

anchor.surface_text: the assessing authority came to the companyclusion that the transactions were inter-State sales within the meaning of Sec. 3  a  of the Central Sales Tax Act and since the appellant was the first dealer in matches in Mysore State it was liable to pay Sales Tax and accordingly, it was so assessed. Against the said assessment order the appellant filed an appeal to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes who dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal to Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Against the said assessment order the appellant filed an appeal to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes who dismissed the appeal. The further appeal to the Tribunal was equally unsuccessful.

facts.text: Appeal to Tribunal was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The further appeal to the Tribunal was equally unsuccessful. Before us it is companytended by the learned Advocate for the appellant relying upon the despatch advice, delivery numberes and invoices issued in the name of the assessee in which the Sales Tax 2 was charged that the sale by the manufacturer at Sivakasi was effected in favour of their respective sales Depots in Mysore

facts.text: Appellant contends that sale by manufacturer at Sivakasi was to sales depots first, based on despatch advice, delivery notes, invoices charging Sales Tax.

anchor.surface_text: Before us it is companytended by the learned Advocate for the appellant relying upon the despatch advice, delivery numberes and invoices issued in the name of the assessee in which the Sales Tax 2 was charged that the sale by the manufacturer at Sivakasi was effected in favour of their respective sales Depots in Mysore and it is only thereafter that the appellants purchased from these Sales Depots the matches and cannot therefore be treated as the first purchaser in the Mysore State.

facts.text: Facts set out above were not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us on the facts as set out above which were number in dispute, the sales were made by the respective factories direct to the appellant, the sales price was also sent directly to the factories at Sivakasi.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in that case while this Court was companysidering the question whether the sales were inter-State sales or inside sales, the definition of sale under the Madhya Pradesh Sales Tax Act was number specifically referred to or examined. A perusal of that decision, however, would show that what this Court was companysidering was whether the transactions fell within the definition of sale companytained in explanation 11 to section 2 g  of the Madhya Pradesh Sales Tax Act and that so far as the post-Cons- titution period was companycerned, whether they were saved from the ban of Article 286 1   a  and the explanation thereto, by the Presidents order made under the proviso to Article 286 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case involved MP Sales Tax Act expl II s.2(g), Art. 286 issues, and sales via UP depots/agents; not same as Mysore Act s.2(t) Expl 3 or facts here.
